summary: James R. Schlesinger is mentioned in the documents as the Secretary of Defense in 1975. One document (104-10431-10006) is a memorandum from James Angleton to Schlesinger analyzing Soviet policy towards the United States based on information from a former KGB member. The memo suggests a symposium to discuss the source's views and highlights Soviet efforts in disinformation and technology acquisition. While the other documents do not directly involve Schlesinger, they provide context regarding CIA and FBI activities under review by the Senate Select Committee (SSC) and an inventory of Rockefeller Commission files related to the CIA's activities and the Kennedy assassination. Schlesinger's role appears to be primarily as a recipient of intelligence analysis during his tenure as Secretary of Defense.
significance: While James R. Schlesinger is not directly implicated in the JFK assassination in these documents, his role as Secretary of Defense places him in a position to receive intelligence related to national security matters, including information potentially relevant to understanding the broader context of the Kennedy assassination era. His connection to James Angleton, a key figure in CIA counterintelligence, is also noteworthy.
